name: electricity production, natural gas, conventional power plant | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21911/documentation

This dataset represents the production of high voltage electricity in a conventional natural gas power plant without CHP (combined heat and power) on Argentina in 2014. ;In this category all conventional generation units (steam and gas turbines) consuming natural gas are considered. Gas Turbines and Steam Turbine belonging to combined cycle power plants and cogeneration plants are excluded from this dataset. ;During 2014, most of the Steam Power (SP) plants consumed a mix of Natural Gas and Fuel Oil. The percentage of fuel oil is very high, ranging from 5 up to 95 %, with a median value close to 70%. Only one power plant (San Nicolás) consumed Coal, Natural Gas and Fuel Oil. ;;Gas Turbine power plants (GT) usually consume Natural Gas and Gas Oil. From 43 gas turbines considered in this study, 81 % consumed a mix of Natural Gas and Gas Oil during 2014, and the rest only natural gas. The percentage of Gas Oil consumed ranges from 0,4 % to 64 %, with a median value of 4 %.;An averaged efficiency have been calculated considering the specific consumtion of the gas-consuming generation units and their total amount of electricity produced. ;Supporting documentation available at: <http://portalweb.cammesa.com/Memnet1/default.aspx>. Additional information can be obtained from CAMMESA under request ;For electricity production with natural gas, four different datasets relying to different power plant types exist:; - conventional power plant with / without CHP; - combined cycle power plant with / without CHP;The total amount of electricity produced with natural gas has therefore been allocated to these four types and is modelled in four different datasets (see parameter gross electricity production for information). The resulting shares worldwide amount to 36% (conventional w/o CHP), 23% (conventional with CHP), 36% (combined cycle w/o CHP), 6% (combined cycle with CHP).;At the moment, these different types are mainly modelled based on different electrical and thermal efficiency values. ;The efficiency calculations are based on ;(fuel input vs. electricity produced)  CAMMESA statistics and own calculation assumptions. Supporting documentation available at: <http://portalweb.cammesa.com/Memnet1/default.aspx>. Additional information can be obtained from CAMMESA under request ;Reducing factors such as contaminations of important plant parts, cooling conditions or part load have been taken into account. Even if efficiencies vary with different surrounding temperatures, temperature adjustments would be related to high uncertainties.;Water is used for wet cooling and as feed water in the steam circuit. In this dataset, 100% wet cooling and no once-through cooling is assumed.  ;EMISSIONS:;Different sources served as basis for assumption of average emissions. Where possible, the most recent sources were taken into account, whereas older sources were taken in order to determine the remaining data gaps. The emissions have been calculated for the former UCTE region* and have been taken over as such for all countries (uncertainty adjusted accordingly). See ecoinvent report 'Erdgas' given as main source for details (Tab. 11.15). In the following a short overview:; - Emissions of NOx, CO, CO2, SO2, particles, N2O and CH4 are mainly taken from CORINAIR 2001, EPA, and a variety of other data sources ;-	NOx emissions are a major challenge in natural gas power plants. With rising temperature, emissions also rise; band widths of NOx emissions in literature are correspondingly large. There are several methods to diminish these emissions.;-	CO is a result of incomplete burning. For economic and technical reasons, plant combustion is optimized and CO emissions are low. ;-	CO2 and SO2 emissions are dependent on the composition of the used fuel. Due to the low sulfur content of the used natural gas, no desulfurization has to take place.;-	Organic compound emissions are estimated on the basis of EPA 1998. ;-	Particles are assumed to be smaller than 2.5 micro-m;*former UCTE: Union for the Coordination of the Transmission of Electricity, since 2009 replaced by ENTSO-E European Network of Transmission System Operators for Electricity.;Sources:;-	CORINAIR 2001. EMEP/CORINAIR 2001: Joint EMEP/CORINAIR Atmospheric Emission Inventory Guidebook, Third Edition. Copenhagen: European Environment Agency, 2001. http://reports.eea.eu.int/technical_report_2001_3/en.;-	EPA 1998. US Environmental Protection Agency (1998). Compilation of Air Pollutant Emission Factors, AP-42, Fifth Edition, Volume I: Chapter 1: External Combustion Sources, Natural Gas Combustion - Final Section - Supplement D , July 1998. CHIEF (Clearinghouse for Inventories and Emission Factors). Research Triangle Park, North Carolina. http://www.epa.gov/ttn/chief/ap42/.;-	Rentz O., Karl U., Peter H. (2002). Ermittlung und Evaluierung von Emissionsfaktoren für Feuerungsanlagen in Deutschland für die Jahre 1995, 2000 und 2010. Deutsch- Französisches Institut für Umweltforschung, Uni Karsruhe. Endbericht. Im Auftrag des Umweltbundesamtes. Forschungsbericht 299 43 142. Umweltbundesamt. Berlin.;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

From the constructed natural gas power plant ready to produce electricity. 

From reception of natural gas and operating materials at power plant/factory gate.

This activity ends with 1kWh of high voltage electricity produced at the power plant and arrived at the busbar. 

- all operation and maintenance activities and materials of the power plants.
 - Cooling: In this dataset, 100% once-through cooling system is assumed.
 - Water is used for cooling and as feed water in the steam circuit for losses compensation.

This dataset doesn't include 
 - raw materials extraction, decommissioning and waste treatment as these activities are already included in the infrastructure datasets.
 - transformation of the electricity produced. 


Decarbonised water for Nox reduction has not been included in this dataset. Decarbonised water is also used in recirculating cooling systems, but in this dataset, 100% once-through cooling system is assumed.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The Annual Production Volume is valid for the year 2012.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average inforrmation from all conventional natural gas power plants in Argentina. The plant is used for middle load with 5000 hours of operation at full capacity per year. The plant is assumed to operate 180000 hours during its lifetime.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Exchanges have been extrapolated from the GLO 2008 dataset using the factor_MJ_kWh parameter. 

The efficiency is based on CAMMESA statistics and calculated with own assumptions.
             
Water is used for cooling and as feed water in the steam circuit for compensating losses.  Decarbonised water is used in recirculating cooling systems, but in this dataset, 100% once-through cooling is assumed. 
Decarbonised water is also used in WetDeNOx devices, but according to the information provided by the National Electricity Regulatory Board (Spanish acronym ENRE), which monitors the compliance of the electric generators with current environmental legislation, many of the generation units have DryLowNOx devices installed. Therefore decarbonised water has not been included in this dataset.
Source: CAMMESA "COMPAÑÍA ADMINISTRADORA DEL MERCADO MAYORISTA ELÉCTRICO SOCIEDAD ANÓNIMA" Supporting documentation available at: <http://portalweb.cammesa.com/Memnet1/default.aspx>

ENRE. http://www.enre.gov.ar/web/web.nsf/home?openframeset. INformation available under request
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Literature and statistics. 
This dataset represents all single power plants which consumed Natural Gas during 2014 in Argentina. The net electricity production by these power plants was 14.91 TWh.

Combined power plants and CHP are excluded from this dataset. 

During 2014, most of the Steam Power (SP) plants consumed a mix of Natural Gas and Fuel Oil. The percentage of fuel oil ranged from 5 up to 95 %, with a median value close to 70%. Only one power plant (San Nicolás) consumed Coal, Natural Gas and Fuel Oil. 

Gas Turbine power plants (GT) usually consume Natural Gas and Gas Oil. From 43 gas turbines dispatching electricity during the reference year, 81 % consumed both Natural Gas and Gas Oil, and the rest only natural gas. The percentage of Gas Oil consumed ranges from 0,4 % to 64 %, with a median value of 4 %.
The efficiency calculations are based on CAMMESA "COMPAÑÍA ADMINISTRADORA DEL MERCADO MAYORISTA ELÉCTRICO SOCIEDAD ANÓNIMA" Supporting information available from: http://portalweb.cammesa.com/memnet1/revistas/estacional/datos_termicos.html.

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value, adapted from the GLO 2008 dataset using the mathematical relation taken from the original dataset and adapted for Argentina with the factor_MJ_kWh.

The factor_MJ_kWh has been calculated with information retrieved from CAMMESA for the 2014 year: 
CAMMESA "COMPAÑÍA ADMINISTRADORA DEL MERCADO MAYORISTA ELÉCTRICO SOCIEDAD ANÓNIMA" . Supporting documentation available at: <http://portalweb.cammesa.com/Memnet1/default.aspx> Additional information can be obtained from CAMMESA under request

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 
Water is used for cooling and as feed water in the steam circuit for compensating losses.  This value have been adapted from the GLO 2008 dataset using the factor_MJ_kWh.

The factor_MJ_kWh has been calculated with information retrieved from CAMMESA for the 2014 year: 
Decarbonised water is used in recirculating cooling systems, but in this dataset, 100% once-through cooling is assumed. 
Decarbonised water is also used in WetDeNOx devices, but according to the information provided by the National Electricity Regulatory Board (Spanish acronym ENRE), which monitors the compliance of the electric generators with current environmental legislation, many of the combined cycle power plant have DryLowNOx devices installed. Therefore decarbonised water has not been included in this dataset. 

Source: CAMMESA "COMPAÑÍA ADMINISTRADORA DEL MERCADO MAYORISTA ELÉCTRICO SOCIEDAD ANÓNIMA" . Supporting documentation available at: <http://portalweb.cammesa.com/Memnet1/default.aspx> Additional information can be obtained from CAMMESA under request

ENRE, Ente Nacional Regulador de la Electricidad, http://www.enre.gov.ar/web/web.nsf/home?openframeset. Information available under request

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value, adapted from the GLO 2008 dataset using the mathematical relation taken from the original dataset and adapted for Argentina with the factor_MJ_kWh.

The factor_MJ_kWh has been calculated with information retrieved from CAMMESA for the 2014 year: 
CAMMESA "COMPAÑÍA ADMINISTRADORA DEL MERCADO MAYORISTA ELÉCTRICO SOCIEDAD ANÓNIMA" . Supporting documentation available at: <http://portalweb.cammesa.com/Memnet1/default.aspx> Additional information can be obtained from CAMMESA under request

flow.name: Toluene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Statistics/Calculated value. 
This value has been calculated from national statistics provided by CAMMESA,  considering the specific consumption of all single generation units which consume natural gas. This figure was scaled to the Ecoinvent standard heating value or 39 MJ/m3. The actual heating value is 34.7 MJ/m3.
CAMMESA "COMPAÑÍA ADMINISTRADORA DEL MERCADO MAYORISTA ELÉCTRICO SOCIEDAD ANÓNIMA" 
Supporting documentation available at: <http://portalweb.cammesa.com/Memnet1/default.aspx>
